awd_titl_txt: Interactive Inner Asia: documenting an endangered language contact area
awd_abstract_narration: The project has two interrelated objectives: to produce a database-backed website on the Inner Asian Sprachbund languages, and an etymological dictionary of the Inner Asian Salar language. The area remains largely undocumented as a Sprachbund. Typological and lexical databases with extensive metadata provide a coordinating instrument with which to study study language contact and change. Integrating extensive examples from exising corpora allows research at all levels of linguistics. Here, an exhaustive dictionary of one language, Salar [ISO 639-3: slr], serves as a test case to be integrated with data from four other endangered lan­gua­ges from the region, Baonan [peh], Wutun [wuh], Kangjia [kxs], and Southeastern Monguor [mjg]. The result will be a new tool, in the form of integrated datasets, for the study of language contact and change. The website will be a major online resource of a linguistic area, including information on area's dominant languages, North­western Mandarin and Amdo Tibetan. Language and cultural contact in the strategically important Inner Asian linguistic area is very poorly understood, and this project's fresh research in China, detailed website and online forum will provide a  needed resource for China and Central Asia scholars and policy  makers, as well as for linguists and language community members.

por.por_cntn:
The language communities of the northern Tibetan plateau represent current and former powerful groups: Chinese, Tibetans, Mongols, and Turks. They have interacted intensely over at least the last six centuries, leading to a convergence even between unrelated languages and cultures. For 15 years, descendants of Genghis Khan's Mongols (and Turks) previously worked with this project's lead researcher to make recordings of their now endangered languages. This current project created a website to share transcriptions and translations of sample recordings, as well as resources on five endangered languages of the area: Salar, Baonan, Wutun, Kangjia, Mangghuer. It shows these five languages undergoing varying degrees of influence from the two now-dominant languages of the area, Chinese and Tibetan. And it shows that even the dominant languages were also strongly influenced by these “smaller” languages. By understanding this one linguistic area, similar developments in other linguistic areas in the world are clarified.

As a result, languages of northern Tibet big and small have come to resemble each other, albeit in varying ways. What linguistic, social, and ecological reasons led to these differences is interesting for research. So by making closely-analyzed data from these endangered languages available, the public is able to investigate further: what are the differences and similarities? What led to these changes in language?

International collaboration, in particular indigenous-academic collaboration, was at the heart of this project. Indigenous researchers in China position themselves in this project as active research partners, not research subjects, which reflects recent developments in the ethical practice in research. Sharing and creating a discussion and teaching forum is particularly appropriate for Chinese, US-based, and other audiences. It is a significant resource not just for research, but also for teaching, and in particular for building the University of Kansas' fledgling Central Asia graduate program. And ten students were trained and gained experience on this project.
